awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CICI: Secure and Resilient Architecture: SciGuard: Building a Security Architecture for Science DMZ Based on SDN and NFV Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
As data-intensive science becomes the norm in many fields of science, high-performance data transfer is rapidly becoming a standard cyberinfrastructure requirement. To meet this requirement, an increasingly large number of university campuses have deployed Science DMZs. A Science DMZ is a portion of the network, built at or near the edge of the campus or laboratory's network, that is designed such that the equipment, configuration, and security policies are optimized for high-performance scientific applications rather than for general-purpose computing. This project develops a secure and resilient architecture called SciGuard that addresses the security challenges and the inherent weaknesses in Science DMZs. SciGuard is based on two emerging networking paradigms, Software-Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Function Virtualization (NFV), both of which enable the granularity, flexibility and elasticity needed to secure Science DMZs. 

Two core security functions, an SDN firewall application and a virtual Intrusion Detection System (IDS), coexist in SciGuard for protecting Science DMZs. The SDN firewall application is a software-based, in-line security function running atop the SDN controller. It can scale well without bypassing the firewall using per-flow/per-connection network traffic processing.  It is also separated from the institutional hardware-based firewalls to enforce tailored security policies for the science-only traffic sent to Science DMZs. The virtual IDS is an NFV-based, passive security function, which can be quickly instantiated and elastically scaled to deal with attack traffic variations in Science DMZs, while significantly reducing both equipment and operational costs. In addition to these functions, the researchers also design a cloud-based federation mechanism for SciGuard to support security policy automatic testing and security intelligence sharing. The new mechanisms developed in this project are robust, scalable, low cost, easily managed, and optimally provisioned, therefore substantially enhancing the security of Science DMZs. This research encourages the diversity of students involved in the project by active recruitment of women and other underrepresented groups for participation in the project. The project has substantial involvement of graduate students in research, and trains promising undergraduate students in the implementation and experiments of the proposed approach. Moreover, the project enhances academic curricula by integrating the research findings into new and existing courses.

por.por_cntn:
There is a critical need to design a new security solution that is scalable, flexible, and cost effective to adapt to Science DMZ protection needs. The major goal of this project is to develop a secure and resilient architecture called SciGuard that addresses the security challenges and the inherent weaknesses in Science DMZs. SciGuard is based on two emerging networking paradigms, Software-Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Function Virtualization (NFV), both of which enable the granularity, flexibility and elasticity needed to secure Science DMZs.

This project has investigated an SDN firewall application, FlowMon, which is a software-based in-line security function running atop the SDN controller. It is also separated by institutional hardware-based firewalls to enforce tailored security policies against the science-only traffic in Science DMZs.

This project has also investigated a couple of challenges for supporting virtual Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) elastic scaling. The project has proposed a new NIDS architecture, vNIDS, to enable the safe and efficient virtualization of IDSes. vNIDS addresses two key challenges with respect to effective intrusion detection and non-monolithic NIDS provisioning in virtualizing NIDS. The project has further developed a side-channel based anomaly detection system for traffic winnowing to reduce the volume of traffic reflected in the virtual NIDS instances for protecting Science DMZs and proposed a lightweight and trusted execution environment for securing virtual network functions. In addition, the project has presented an approach to explaining the outcome of deep learning-based NIDS to generate SDN flow rules to enable dynamic network access control for Science DMZs.

This project has additionally introduced a high-speed feature extractor with the help of both programmable switches to accelerate deep learning-based traffic analysis and developed a fast and scalable in-network scanner and a system for enabling cost-efficient and agile DDoS defense based on programmable switches. Besides, the project has designed SDN and NFV security education materials and labs to engage students in learning about SDN and NFV security.

The relevant research results from this project have been published in NDSS 2017, IEEE/ACM TON, SDN-NFV Security 2017, IEEE CNS 2017, IEEE TDSC CCS 2018, SDN-NFV Security 2018, Computer & Security, SDN-NFV Security 2019, RAID 2019, ICC 2019 ,EEE Communications Surveys & Tutorials, MSN 2020, MLHat 2020, and ACM SACMAT 2020.  This research project has also supported the training and professional development of two Ph.D. students and one MS student.

Modified by: Gail-Joon Ahn
